2025-05-03 20:37:52,504 - together_inference - INFO - [{'role': 'system', 'content': 'You are given one sentence related to the Bank of Thailand\'s monetary policy meeting. You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: moreover, although domestic inflation remained high, short-run inflationary pressures from the government’s stimulus package may not be material given the implementation time lag and only a small disbursement was expected in the second half of the year.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:37:52,505 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that short-run inflationary pressures from the government's stimulus package may not be material, implying that the inflationary impact is limited and therefore reducing the urgency for tightening monetary policy."
}

influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, credit assistance measures partially relieved liquidity constraints of businesses and households affected by the covid-19 pandemic.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:37:55,579 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that credit assistance measures have relieved liquidity constraints, which suggests that the monetary policy has been effective in supporting economic growth and easing financial conditions."
}

Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the global economy expanded at a slower pace compared with the assessment in the previous meeting due mainly to weaker asian economies, in particular china.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:37:58,408 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a slower pace of global economic expansion, which hints at potential easing measures."
}

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t     ### Sentence: the growth forecast for 2017 was revised up from 3.4 percent to 3.5 percent.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:01,805 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports an upward revision of the growth forecast, suggesting a stronger economy and potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: inflation thus was not an immediate threat; (3) risks to financial stability decreased somewhat, reflected by decelerating private credit growth amid economic slowdown.\n                '}]

"justification": "The sentence indicates that inflation is not an immediate threat and risks to financial stability decreased, suggesting a more relaxed monetary policy stance."

influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: moreover, investors would search for higher yields across almost all asset classes, which could lead to underpricing of risks.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:05,383 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that investors may take on excessive risk, leading to potential market instability, which could prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: private investment was expected to expand due to the relocation of production base to thailand and ppp infrastructure investment projects which showed signs of continued progress.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:08,798 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates an expected expansion of private investment, which suggests economic growth and potential easing of monetary policy."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the financial positions of some households remained fragile from the impact of covid-19 as their incomes had yet to fully recover.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:11,599 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that some households' financial positions are fragile due to the impact of COVID-19, suggesting a need for accommodative monetary policy to support economic recovery."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the price-earnings ratio (p/e ratio) was thus largely unchanged.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence simply reports that the price-earnings ratio remained unchanged, providing no indication of inflationary pressures or economic growth, and therefore does not convey a specific monetary policy stance."

influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: private consumption and investment was expected to expand in line with good prospects for both farm and non-farm income, improved confidence, expansion in credit, and rising investment trend in the automobile, electronics and electrical appliance industries.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:15,160 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates an expansion in private consumption and investment, which suggests a growing economy and reduced need for monetary tightening."
}

this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: in addition, the committee expressed concerns over the potential negative impact arising from an extended period of slow economic recovery and weak private sector confidence.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:17,473 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence expresses concerns over slow economic recovery and weak private sector confidence, hinting at potential downside risks to economic growth, which suggests a dovish stance."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai investment.\n                '}]

    ### Sentence: this, however, might not lead to additional investment in the near term, as spare production capacity should remain in many industries.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:20,078 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that spare production capacity will remain in many industries, implying that there is no immediate need for additional investment, which hints at a dovish stance."
}
