You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nonetheless, there were notable risks to this outlook, particularly as the thai exports might not fully reap the benefits of the global demand recovery and the electronic cycle upturn due to multifaceted structural hurdles.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence highlights risks to the outlook, specifically structural hurdles that may hinder the benefits of global demand recovery, implying potential downside risks to economic growth and thus a dovish stance."
}

influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nevertheless, recent portfolio inflows to thailand were smaller in size compared with inflows to other countries in the region.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:23,636 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence provides information about portfolio inflows to Thailand compared to other countries in the region, but it does not convey any clear indication of the monetary policy stance."
}

this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: nonetheless, they could not fully offset the weaker momentum of domestic demand and exports of goods amid two main factors restraining economic recovery: (1) the slowdown in the chinese and other asian economies which should subject exports of goods to further contraction, although the recent weakening of the baht might help buoy exports to some extent, and (2) domestic drought which could weigh down the already-weak recovery of private consumption through a decline in farm income and private confidence.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:28,281 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates downside risks to economic growth, including weaker domestic demand and exports, and highlights factors restraining economic recovery, suggesting potential easing measures."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht     ### Sentence: the japanese economy moderated as domestic demand fell short of expectation in the first quarter, with the increase in consumption tax impeding private consumption.\n see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: these included (1) the number of foreign tourists that could increase less than previously assessed due to risks that the second wave of the outbreak in many countries could result in changes in attitude and behavior regarding international travel, and (2) private consumption that could be dampened by deteriorated household incomes, elevated household debt, and low agencies to explore additional measures to restore the economy, particularly the appropriate travel protocols for foreign tourists.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates potential downside risks to economic growth, specifically in foreign tourism and private consumption, which hints at potential easing measures."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the committee thus revised down the headline inflation forecast for 2016 from 0.8 percent to 0.6 percent, and lowered this year’s core inflation forecast slightly from 0.9 percent to 0.8 percent.\n                '}]

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the upside risk of inflation could come from two factors.\n                '}]

"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions upside risks to inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: global inflationary pressure remained low.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:37,305 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence reports low global inflationary pressure, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggests less inflationary pressure."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, in india and indonesia the policy interest rates were raised in response to elevated inflationary pressure and widening current account deficits; while in the euro area economies the policy interest rate was lowered in response to the economic slowdown amidst subdued inflationary pressure.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence discusses monetary policy actions in other countries (India, Indonesia, and the Euro area) without providing any information about the Bank of Thailand's stance or actions."

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: given subdued domestic demand and stable world crude oil prices, inflation was not an immediate threat; (3) improved global financial market sentiments helped contain capital flows and exchange rate risks; and exposed to economic slowdown, such as small and medium enterprises and households.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:45,046 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence mentions subdued domestic demand, stable oil prices, and improved global financial market sentiments, indicating a lack of inflationary pressures and a stable economic environment, which suggests a dovish stance."
}

measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: therefore, the committee saw the need to monitor the income recovery and financial positions of the vulnerable groups.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:48,000 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence does not convey any information about the monetary policy stance, it only mentions the committee's need to monitor the income recovery and financial positions of vulnerable groups, which is a neutral statement."
}

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: as such, the committee would monitor and assess these developments closely.\n                '}]

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. &
