Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: global inflation remained stable relative to the previous meeting, though pressure from an elevated oil price level persisted.\n                '}]

"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence reports that global inflation remained stable, but also mentions pressure from elevated oil prices, indicating no clear direction for monetary policy."
}

held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: there were outflows from both the bond and equity markets, with rising bond yields and baht depreciation against the us dollar.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:38:57,580 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports outflows from bond and equity markets, rising bond yields, and baht depreciation, indicating potential inflationary pressures and a need for a tighter monetary policy stance."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: short- and medium-term thai government bond yields rose due to (1) recent economic and inflation outturns which were better than expected and (2) an foreign investors continued to sell off emerging market short-term bonds.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:39:00,989 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "hawkish",
"justification": "The sentence reports an increase in Thai government bond yields, which suggests a tightening of monetary policy due to better-than-expected economic and inflation outturns."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low     ### Sentence: private investment indicators improved across various sectors, while private consumption continued to expand in line with improvements in household purchasing power and consumer Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: third, the continued economic recovery of trading partners would benefit thai exports.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence suggests that the economic recovery of trading partners would benefit Thai exports, implying a positive impact on the economy and reducing the need for monetary tightening."
}

held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: however, the root cause of such issues stemmed from borrowers’ credit risks and lenders’ limitations in assessing the risks of smaller firms, all of which cannot be addressed solely through monetary policy.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:39:07,130 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "irrelevant",
"justification": "The sentence discusses the limitations of monetary policy in addressing credit risks and lender limitations, but does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance."
}

influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: moreover, foreign investors also reduced holdings of emerging market assets, affecting thai equity and bond markets.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:39:10,011 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates a reduction in foreign investors' holdings of emerging market assets, which could lead to a decrease in demand for Thai assets, potentially easing monetary policy."
}

You are also given an annotation guide for the feature: stance.\n            Strictly follow the guide; do not invent new criteria or labels.\n\n            Your task is to classify whether it is "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant" and briefly justify your choice.\n            \n            Instructions:\n            1. Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n Provide a concise explanation for your classification using the `justification` key. Limit the justification to one sentence.\n            \n            3. Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': 'Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{bot}{9} Inflation, Economic Growth, Copper Prices, Peso Exchange Rate, Foreign Reserves, External Demand (Trade Partners), Key Words/Phrases, Labor Market, and Energy Prices. \n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the state of the economy, relating to factors such as unemployment and inflation.\n    \\item \\emph{Thai Baht Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to the appreciation or depreciation of the Thai Baht in the foreign exchange market.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in energy sectors or housing prices, indicative of broader economic conditions.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Policy}: A sentence pertaining to trade relations and economic interactions between Thailand and its international partners. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: these included the rebalancing toward consumption in place of investment as a driver of growth, urbanization policy to expand developments to the inner cities, as well as the promotion of labor mobility to support domestic demand growth.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:39:13,953 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence discusses policies aimed at promoting domestic demand growth, which suggests a focus on supporting economic growth and employment, indicating a dovish stance."
}

held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of Thailand}} \\label{tb:bot_mp_stance_guide} \\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: financial stability had already been addressed to some extent but there remained pockets of risks that warranted monitoring.\n                '}]
2025-05-03 20:39:16,941 - together_inference - INFO - Response: {
"label": "neutral",
"justification": "The sentence neither indicates a clear direction for monetary policy nor suggests any specific risks or concerns that would warrant a hawkish or dovish stance."
}

Assign one of the following labels under the `label` key:\n            "hawkish", "neutral", "dovish", or "irrelevant"\n            \n            2. If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge negative effect. & \nMPC’s expectations of future economic status remainings uncertain because there is not much indicator for which way the economic status should sway. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & \nMoney supply is low, M2 measure increases, increased demand for loans. & \nMoney supply is high, increased demand for goods, low demand for loans. & \nN/A. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & \nWhen the stance is "accommodative", indicating a focus on “maximum employment” and “price stability”. & \nIndicating a focus on “price stability” and “sustained growth”. & \nUse of phrases “mixed”, “moderate”, “reaffirmed. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Labor Market} & \nWhen labor markets see improvements, Thailand’s policy is more dovish because it leads to lower inflationary pressure to support economic growth and employment. & \nWhen labor markets see a decline, Thailand’s policy can be more hawkish because it can increase inflationary pressures due to more limited supplies. & \nWhen labor markets don’t see a change in the productivity of labor markets, there isn’t a change in the monetary policy. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: these uncertainties subsequently impinged on economic activities, especially production and merchandise exports.\n                '}]

"label": "dovish",
"justification": "The sentence indicates that uncertainties have negatively impacted economic activities, suggesting downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures."
}

If not directly related, the sentence is labeled neutral.\n    \\item \\emph{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets}: A sentence that discusses the MPC\'s projections, actions, or asset valuations, influencing monetary policy decisions.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that overtly discusses changes in the money supply or shifts in the demand for loans.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words/Phrases}: A sentence that encapsulates specific key words or phrases which classify monetary policy stances based on their conventional usage.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor Market}: A sentence pertaining to changes in labor market performance and productivity that may affect monetary policy.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\\paragraph{Examples:}\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``The latest risk-adjusted inflation forecast for 2024 eased to 3.9 percent from 4.2 percent in the previous meeting in December.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: The sentence reports a decline in inflation forecast, which reduces the urgency for tightening of monetary policy and suggest less inflationary pressure.\n\n    \\item ``Headline inflation increased in June and July driven mainly by rising transport costs such as higher domestic petroleum prices and tricycle fare hikes.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: This sentence highlights an increase in headline inflation, suggesting potential inflationary pressures that may prompt a tighter monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``The highlights of the discussions on the 1st December 2011 meeting were approved by the monetary board during its regular meeting held on 15th Decemeber 2011.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The sentence is simply procedural and does not provide any information about the monetary policy stance.\n    \n    \\item ``Nonetheless, inflation forecasts for 2016-2017 stayed close to the midpoint of the target range.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence indicates that the inflation forecasts remained near the midpoint of the target range, it implies that inflation is stable but does not convey any information on need for monetary tightening or easing. \n    \n    \\item ``However, the moderation in growth in Q1 2014, particularly in the US, as well as tighter financial conditions and geopolitical tensions in the Middle East and Russia, could dampen the overall momentum for the rest of 2014.\'\'\\\\ \n    \\textbf{Dovish}: This sentence indicates some downside risks to economic growth, which hints at potential easing measures.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\n\n\n\n\n\\newpage\n\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & \nWhen inflation decreases, When unemployment increases, when economic growth is projected as low. & \nWhen inflation increases, when unemployment decreases when economic growth is projected high when economic output is higher than potential supply/actual output when economic slack falls. & \nWhen unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Thai Baht Value Change} & \nWhen the Thai Baht appreciates. & \nWhen the Thai Baht depreciates. & \nWhen there is no real change in Thai Baht worth. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Energy/House Prices} & \nWhen oil/energy sectors dwindle and prices decrease, when housing prices decrease because this can indicate a smaller consumer output, and with a dovish economy there will be a larger consumer output. & \nWhen oil/energy sectors are augmented/prices increase, when housing prices increase because this can indicate a large consumer output, and the economy could benefit from a hawkish policy as it will help stabilize prices. & \nWhen there is market uncertainty in the oil/energy sectors, when housing prices have an uncertain outlook as this means there is not clear indicators on how consumer spending is. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{Foreign Policy} & \nWhen partner economics are starting to expand, Thailand’s monetary policy will be more free as Thailand’s economic output throughput is directly proportional to its trading partners. & \nWhen partner economies are starting to fall or become highly volatile, Thailand should be more hawkish as the partner trading profitability is uncertain. & \nWhen describing specifics on an unrelated foreign nation’s economic or trade policy as this is likely to have little effect on the monetary policy control for Thailand or uncertainty in partners economies. & \nSentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\n\\textbf{MPC Expectations/Actions/ Assets} & \nMPC expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing of spread in Thai government bonds/lower yields, low debt serviceability because in these cases, it is in best interest to allow a freer monetary policy to boost spending/market growth. & \nMPC expects high inflation, widening of spread in Thai government bonds/higher yields, high debt serviceability because in these cases, the market has some room in which the monetary policy may be more strict without a huge
